113.description:
You can make any website a Progressive Web App, but how can you give it that native look and feel?

During this talk, we'll cover the pillars for native-like PWAs, as well as multiple UX & performance strategies such as the app update process, code splitting, advanced app shells, UX & more.

These techniques will make your PWA indistinguishable from a native app, while taking advantage of the benefits of the web.
113.title: Secrets of Native-like PWAs

114.description:
A system is as secure as its weakest component. Imagine having a state-of-the-art Firewall to protect your devices from anything outside of your network. Are you secure? What if you connect your laptop to your home network after having used it in a bar?
Ok well, let’s say you also have one of the best Advanced Malware Protection software installed on every device you own, are you protected now? The answer to this is simple, can you really install such software onto all your devices? Even the IoT devices? 
In this talk, we will address how a multi-layered approach, with a separation of concern, to security can better protect your system.
114.title: The case for a layered approach to Cyber Security

115.description:
Threats are always evolving, and so must Security Solutions if we want to keep our networks and devices protected. In this talk we will explore how the use of an open ecosystem of API-enabled Security Solutions allows us to not only greatly improve the overall protection, but also drastically increase its customizability and personalization, enabling a much finer tuning to the very specific requirements dictated by your network, your devices, your company. 
Hackers share information and intel in many forums, so why shouldn’t we use the same approach to improve our defenses? 

Most companies only have an antivirus installed on the devices they own and a Firewall to protect the internal network, but is that really the best solution? What if we would be able to build a script that, once a ransomware is detected on a device, it would automatically and instantly protect all your devices on and off the company’s network, preventing the malware from communicating with the Command and Control Server?
115.title: The desperate need for open, cooperating and automated security solutions – Two Cisco's examples

116.description: Smartphone and smart glasses manufacturers like Google, Apple and Microsoft are increasing the number of available devices with mixed reality features. The environmental understanding capability allows the developers to create a totally new kind of experience for the users using framework like ARCore, ARKit or Microsoft Mixer Reality Toolkit. They provide a deep merging between the virtual and the real world around us. It's easy to make mistakes so the users can feel uncomfortable living the experiences with our AR apps. In this workshop we discuss the best approach to design good user interfaces and provide a shine natural interaction for the user based on mixed reality paradigm.
116.title: UI/UX App Design @ Mixed Reality Age

117.description:
Diversity & Inclusion ||
What Is Inclusion and Why Does It Matter?
Building, Sustaining, and Benefiting from Diversity 
Cross-Cultural Communication
Cultural Identity and Cultural Values at Work
117.title: Inclusion as the Key

118.description: In questo talk andremo ad espolare la libreria Rxjs dalla base capendo cosa è un observable e cosa è la programmazione funzionale reattiva,e come applicare ciò in un contesto pratico
118.title: Understanding Rxjs from the ground up!

119.description: In this workshop you will put in practice, through a fun “treasure hunt” like scenario, how the many APIs exposed by Cisco’s Security Products will allow you to detect, investigate, identify and isolate the threat that got into your network. All of this with the help of Python and REST APIs.
119.title: Hands on Cisco Security APIs

120.description:
The No Free Lunch Theorem states that there exists no learning algorithm better than any other given one, thus making it necessary for a ML Engineer to know their ways around multiple ways to tackle a problem.
In this talk we'll have a look at common algorithms and models that a ML Engineer should know and when to actually use them.
120.title: No Free Lunch Theorem: Machine Learning 101

121.description:
JavaScript is an extremely common language whose core was developed in 10 days in 1995. Doing things with such a haste left some troubles in the core language that haven't been fixed.
In this talk, we'll look at some snippets of code to highlight some of the unusualities that JavaScript brings.
121.title: JavaScript Shenanigans

122.description:
L'evoluzione del mondo cloud ha portato allo sviluppo di nuovi paradigmi, come ad esempio i microservizi. In questo talk verranno analizzati i pro ed i contro di una infrastruttura a microservizi rispetto a quelle basate sui monoliti.
Queste nuove tecnologie permettono ai nostri servizi di essere più efficienti, scalabili e affidabili. Scopriremo come i microservizi ci permettono di testare e deployare le nostre applicazioni rapidamente.
Inoltre vedremo, con degli esempi, come abbandonare il nostro ormai obsoleto monolite per migrare su questo nuovo paradigma.
122.title: Speed up our application with Microservices

123.description: The talk is about the speakers' experience in taking technical decisions, as a software engineer and as a a technical manager.
123.title: Taking technical decisions

124.description: Adatteremo insieme un progetto Flutter per il Mobile alla sua versione per Web e Desktop dimostrando come con un unico sorgente riusciamo a eseguire Flutter su tutte le piattaforme: Android, iOS, macOS, Windows e Web.
124.title: Flutter: da Mobile a Web e Desktop

125.description:
Talk sia tecnico che motivazionale/strategico, adatto a tutti ma in particolar modo pensato per gli sviluppatori, che spesso sono avulsi dal Cloud.
Invece il rapporto Devs/Cloud è di grande rilevanza, perché la realizzazione di Sistemi Applicativi flessibili e scalabili è e sarà sempre più un grande elemento di successo. Ma per questo ci vogliono gli skill adatti.

Parte strategica:
Le possibilità pratiche - come prepararsi e come qualificarsi - cosa è importante sapere. 
Lo scenario attuale dell’offerta: nonsoloGoogle ma anche AWS ed Azure.
Cosa offre Google ai Dev. Doni ed Opportunità.
Community ed Expert program.

Parte tecnica:
Firebase e GCP: servizi in comune, differenze. Cosa usare e come.
Serverless  e Limitless con Cloud RUN: operativi in tempi brevi → Codelabs e CI/CD
Qwiklabs ed altro: imparare senza rischiare di spendere una lira…
Professional Cloud Developer Certification: la vogliamo fare insieme?
125.title: Serverless and Limitless

126.description:
Se anche Flutter sta crescendo a passi da gigante per la codifica multi-piattaforma su iOS e Android,
grazie alla integrazione  del supporto al web, al desktop e ai dispositivi embedded, promette lo sviluppo di applicazioni per ‘qualsiasi cosa’ da un singolo codebase.
Durante il talk parleremmo di Hummingbird, il progetto che ci permette l’esecuzione del nostro codice Flutter, non solo nei cellulari, ma anche nei browser.
126.title: Flutter For Web

127.description: Firebase rende incredibilmente facile scrivere, distribuire e scalare funzioni e servizi backend senza preoccuparsi dell’infrastruttura e di framework/librerie. Ma quali sono le reali potenzialità e (soprattutto) cosa dobbiamo fare per non cedere al lato oscuro ed implementare correttamente API REST, trigger automatici o funzioni custom? In questo talk esploreremo il paradigma “serverless” offerto da Firebase e come sfruttarlo per rendere la galassia un posto (leggermente) migliore.
127.title: Firebase Functions - Il lato chiaro della Forza

128.description: Firebase rende incredibilmente facile scrivere, distribuire e scalare funzioni e servizi backend senza preoccuparsi dell’infrastruttura e di framework/librerie. La galassia non è un luogo perfetto ed in questo talk analizzeremo situazioni limite (e il lato oscuro) di una tecnologia fantastica che va utilizzata correttamente. Come progettare al meglio i nostri servizi? Come evitare problemi di produzione e ottimizzare le nostre funzioni, quali sistemi abbiamo per schedulare job e/o creare funzioni adatte a situazioni atipiche?
128.title: Firebase Functions - Il lato oscuro della Forza

129.description: Spesso parliamo di cosa sappiamo, in questo talk invece affronteremo dei concetti chiave che forse (noi tutti) ignoriamo sulle community! Perchè farne parte? Cosa potrò ricevere ma soprattutto cosa dare? Perchè insieme possiamo rendere il mondo un posto, leggermente, migliore!
129.title: Una lista di cose che potremmo NON sapere sulle community

130.description: Gestire un team è complesso, alcune volte sembra quasi di essere soli durante l’esplorazione spaziale! Ma nessun grande lavoro può essere fatto senza un grande team. “Da grandi team grandi responsabilità”, non era proprio così… Ma cosa dovresti fare per aiutare il tuo gruppo a raggiungere gli obiettivi? E quali pratiche sane dovresti introdurre per rendere il luogo di lavoro, un pò, migliore?
130.title: Manage Teams, a space adventure!

131.description:
Sicurezza, coraggio e delle buone slide di supporto riescono a sbloccare, davanti al pubblico, anche la persona più timida. 
Vi spiegherò nel dettaglio tutto ciò che succede prima-durante-dopo il vostro talk dandovi alcuni consigli utili, e perché oramai tutti parlano di public speaking.
131.title: Come tenere un talk

132.description:
Youtube is the most used video sharing website in the world and contains a volume of video and data that is impressive to imagine, its ease of use hides the complexity of the data required for its operation and especially for monetization.

In this talk we will see how we managed to interact with the economic reports of many Youtube channels, import a large volume of data through Google's APIs and create a web service based on the intelligent aggregation of these data.

To interact with the Youtube Reports API and to download the data, we used the official Python client library for Google's discovery based APIs.

To create the Web service and all asynchronous task we used Django Web Framework and the uWSGI application server.

To store the large volume of data and import it quickly we used the PostgreSQL database.
132.title: Manage Youtube reports with Django and PostgreSQL

133.description: In this workshop you will learn how to develop an Action to learn a new language
133.title: Google Assistant as a teacher!

134.description: Neural Networks are, more often than not, treated as black boxes: there’s this strange idea of them copying the human brain in such a complex way that no human could ever understand, but that couldn’t be farther from the truth. Neural Networks are actually, conceptually, quite simple in how they work and make up for their simplicity by adding more and more stuff on top of them. Knowing how Neural Networks work is a must for anyone who wants to work in the field of Machine Learning, but even as a bystander having a clear mental image of how stuff works can open your mind to new concepts. In this session we’ll completely demystify how Neural Networks of all kinds work, not by completely disregarding the math side of things, but by actually using it in a human way (instead of cold artificial matrix multiplications).
134.title: Neural Networks for Humans: demystifying the math

135.description:
Millions of people swap selfies on Snapchat or play Super Mario Run every day. Do you know where these apps are running? It's the venerable Google App Engine and the infrastructure of Google Cloud that allow developers to focus on their code and let it scaler the application to Google.
Whether you are deploying applications with App Engine, or functions with Cloud Functions, you no longer worry about servers or clusters to provision and you pay proportionately for usage, with no fixed costs.
In this session, let's find out together what's under the hood, and especially Google's new "serverless" beyond App Engine and Cloud Functions.
135.title: A brave new world. "Serverless" computing on Google Cloud.

136.description: In questa sessione inizieremo con una retrospettiva storica sulla diffusione delle reti neurali, dalla nascita, attraverso i lunghi inverni, fino ad arrivare ai recenti successi del deep learning. Uno dei massimi risultati del deep learning è stato AlphaGo, il programma che per la prima volta è riuscito a battere i più forti giocatori di Go al mondo. Vedremo a grandi linee il funzionamento di AlphaGo e parleremo anche del progetto SAI, il cui obiettivo è far evolvere AlphaGo consentendogli di giocare in condizioni di svantaggio e con uno stile di gioco più "umano".
136.title: Dal percettrone ad AlphaGo (e SAI)

137.description: GraphQL è entrato ormai nello stack di molti sviluppatori e pare voglia soppiantare ciò che REST ha fatto fino ad ora. Tramite esempi pratici, vedremo prima come sia possibile implementare un server GraphQL utilizzando Apollo, approfondendo le opportunità offerte da questo intero ecosistema, per poi passare ad interrogare il server tramite Angular, cercando di capire come cambia lo sviluppo frontend sia dal punto di vista di comunicazione con le API che dal punto di vista dello State Management. Il tutto sperando che la concorrenza non ci RESTi male! :D
137.title: GraphQL con Apollo e Angular - Tutto il REST è noia!

138.description: The speech approach the problem of being driver of changes in a company that oppose resistance to the changes,expose the threshold between change the company or evaluate the next job hop in a constant professional growth path.
138.title: Change the company or Change company

139.description: What are developers’ nightmares? My personal answer is getting lost in overdesign, unchecked mutability and code verbosity. And this is why my talk will be about functional programming: because it deals with these problems pretty smartly. After more than two and a half years working almost exclusively with a functional language, Clojure, in production, I would like to share my experience, discuss what all this fuss about functional programming is and why someone who has always worked with objects should care.
139.title: Functional programming: why should I care?

140.description: Dipendente o imprenditore? Quali sono le ragioni per cui vale la pena scegliere l'una o l'altra strada? Ti racconto la mia storia partendo dalle giornate passate a studiare e a scrivere codice, dalle serate davanti al PC a lavorare per la mia startup oltreoceano, fino alla nascita dell'azienda dei mie sogni per la quale avrei voluto sempre lavorare. Parleremo inoltre di superpoteri, limiti e tanto altro, con l'obiettivo di farti tornare a casa con tanti suggerimenti utili, sia se sei in procinto di avviare la tua impresa sia se lavori per un'azienda.
140.title: Da developer a imprenditore, vi racconto la mia storia

JadJoubran.bio:
Jad is a Google Developer Expert and fullstack teacher.

He's on a mission to inspire developers around the world by coaching at Le Wagon coding bootcamp and regularly speaking at international conferences.

Lately, Jad's focus lies on spreading knowledge about Progressive Web Apps and mentoring developers through online courses, blog articles and workshops for startups & enterprises.
JadJoubran.name: Jad Joubran
JadJoubran.shortBio: FullStack teacher in Amsterdam, Brussels & London
JadJoubran.title: FullStack teacher in Amsterdam, Brussels & London

AntonellaBlasetti.bio: University Master Degree in Statistics I worked as Application and System Engineer in the International SW Development Lab of IBM in Italy. I was Professor of Relational Database Design at the University La Sapienza of Rome. I am founder and co-owner of Information Design, an IT Consulting Company. I worked as temporary manager (IT and Finance) in the Daimler (Mercedes) Outsourcing Company; I took part in international task forces for defining valuation and transfer strategies of all the assets of big data centers (IBM Mainframes). I have been working in International Software Projects and I have a Big experience in Databases and Data/System Integration. I am a Google Expert Cloud  and I got several certifications: AWS Solutions Architect Associate GOOGLE CLOUD Associate Engineer GOOGLE CLOUD Professional Data Engineer GOOGLE CLOUD Professional Cloud Architect ORACLE Database Administrator Neo4j Certification. I am passionate about Machine Learning and Big Data. Since 2011, I have been Google Developer Group GDG ROMA Founder and Leader. I have always supervised the technical aspects of all activities. We organize any kind of events, from the big ones (600 people) to Labs and long-term training programs. I like to enlist special kinds of events: Several Treasure Hunts with Android apps A GDG rail car Lab traveling to Droidcon A Cloud event for about 350 people in the Mercedes Benz Congress Center with the chance to take a ride with fast and powerful Mercedes cars An I/O extended with kids playing tech in the garden and the training activities: Android Web mobile Development ML Angular Cloud DialogFlow/Action on Google. I organize very active sessions, without long boring lectures. With our help, many people managed to improve their professional life, to get a better job, and to gain more self-confidence and motivation. I am really proud of it and I am grateful to Google for giving me this opportunity.
AntonellaBlasetti.name: Antonella Blasetti
AntonellaBlasetti.shortBio: IT Manager Information Design - Google Developer Expert Cloud - AWS e GCP Cloud Certified - Leader Google Developer Group Roma
AntonellaBlasetti.title: IT Manager Information Design - Google Developer Expert Cloud - AWS e GCP Cloud Certified - Leader Google Developer Group Roma

RihannaKedir.bio: Rihanna is a passionate software engineer, maker and new tech enthusiast. She is Google Developer Expert  in Web Technologies. She strongly believes in the importance of sharing knowledge and experience and that is why in her spare time she does volunteering as mentor and speaker in various communities and events. As co-leader of GDG Rome  and Women TechMakers Ambassador, she participates not only in organizing different kinds of events but also in preparing various types of technical and non technical contents and speaks.
RihannaKedir.name: Rihanna Kedir
RihannaKedir.title: GDE web technologies

EliaMaracani.bio:
I'm an Italian guy with a passion for Security, Programming, Technology, and Science in general. 
After graduating from a master degree in Computer Science in Milan Bicocca cum laude, I joined the Cisco program called CSAP working for one year in Amsterdam. I moved back to Italy in mid-2019 and I'm now working as a Technical Solutions Specialist for Cisco in Milan.
EliaMaracani.name: Elia Maracani
EliaMaracani.title: Technical Solutions Specialist, Cisco

VasudevMaduri.bio:
I am Vasudev Maduri, an analytics engineer working at Hitachi Consulting. A machine learning developer by profession. My past works are related to IoT on Google Cloud, Deep Learning with TensorFlow and Cloud Infrastructure management. Currently, am working on a solution for manufacturing industry shop floor automation.

Being a data enthusiast, I learn a lot from the data community and share my experiences & knowledge through my blog, Linkedin etc..
My research areas include predictive analytics, video analytics, and my research work has been published in the "procedia computer science" journal.
VasudevMaduri.name: Vasudev Maduri
VasudevMaduri.title: Technology Enthusiasit, Machine Learning developer

MichelMurabito.bio:
Attualmente ricopre la carica di Deputy Chief Technical Officer in Liscor S.p.A, classe 1986 nato a Torino e cresciuto in Sicilia, inizia a scrivere software per gioco a 12 anni. Primo lavoro a 18 anni come Sviluppatore Software, da lì inizia ad esplorare vari contesti e nuove opportunità di crescita professionale. 
Lavora come dipendente e come libero professionista collaborando ad alcuni progetti tecnologici per la Regione Siciliana e il MiBACT. Contribuisce alla creazione di numerose startup digital e di prodotti innovativi per grossi clienti internazionali. Tra il 2015 e il 2017 si occupa di relazioni con gli sviluppatori, nel team di Developer Relations per una grossa multinazionale Americana. Tra le più grandi passioni quella di raccontare le nuove tecnologie e come gli sviluppatori possono aiutare a creare prodotti migliori; Tra 2017 e il 2019 ha partecipato come speaker a 80 eventi e conferenze in Italia ed Europa.
MichelMurabito.name: Michel Murabito
MichelMurabito.title: Deputy CTO @Liscor (@Lutech Group)

DianaBernabei.bio: Studentessa di Informatica presso l'università di Pisa. Manager del GDG Pisa e WTM ambassador. Sono una sviluppatrice web front-end e amante del coding e della grafica. Nel tempo libero mi piace tenermi aggiornata su design, personal growth e public speaking.
DianaBernabei.name: Diana Bernabei
DianaBernabei.shortBio: WTM ambassador, GDG Pisa manager, CS student
DianaBernabei.title: WTM ambassador, GDG Pisa manager, CS student

ElenaCanovi.bio:
Physicist by training, happy remote worker, I switched to software development in 2017 and since then I have designed, developed and deployed backend software in cloud architectures.
Besides work, I’m an avid reader, I’m very interested in science and tech communication and in the promotion of diversity in STEM.
ElenaCanovi.name: Elena Canovi

StefanoDAlessandro.bio:
Laurea in Informatica, Master in Web Technology, lavora nel mondo IT da ormai 10 anni prima come Developer e poi come Project Manager. Dal 2016 è un Imprenditore Digitale, CEO e Co-Founder di Suredi azienda che nasce con l'obiettivo di progettare e sviluppare prodotti digitali memorabili ;) Stefano è inoltre Co-Founder della Community pescarese Lean Startup Lab che si occupa di far incontrare talenti (Sognatori, Innovatori, Marketers, Sviluppatori, Designer, Imprenditori) e diffondere la metodologia Lean Startup, utile per chi vuole sviluppare un'idea e trasformarla in business evitando sprechi di risorse.
Le sue 3 parole preferite: "SI PUO' FARE!" Ma che cosa si può fare? Beh, crearsi il proprio spazio nel mondo, raccontare la propria storia, sfruttare le proprie passioni ed ambizioni, con curiosità, fame e voglia di fare...cercando di contribuire, con il proprio fare, a rendere il mondo un posto migliore.
StefanoDAlessandro.name: Stefano D'Alessandro
StefanoDAlessandro.title: CEO & Co-Founder @ Suredi

GianMarcoDiFrancesco.bio: Dopo essermi avvicinato per hobby al mondo della programmazione mobile ho iniziato il corso di Informatica Applicata dell'Università di Urbino. Laureato da poco, sviluppo mobile presso Digit Srl (Startup e spinoff universitario) utilizzando Flutter come framework principale.
GianMarcoDiFrancesco.name: Gian Marco Di Francesco
GianMarcoDiFrancesco.title: Sviluppatore mobile presso Digit Srl

MichelantonioTrizio.bio: Engineer & Entrepreneur. I took master degree in computer Engineering with thesis in Artificial Intelligence at Polytechnic University of Bari in 2007. I worked for several years in ICT companies in the south of Italy as developer. I attended the Mind The Bridge startup school in San Francisco in 2011. Back in Italy I started working on my own companies. I'm the founder of GDG Bari and he is the current community lead. Now, I'm the CTO of Wideverse, a spin-off of Polytechnic University of Bari that works on VR and AR technologies. I'm an Android developer.
MichelantonioTrizio.name: Michelantonio Trizio
MichelantonioTrizio.title: CTO @ Wideverse

NicolaGuglielmi.bio:
I started my first computer at 10 and I never stopped researching and learning each single day from then.
I’m a technology enthusiast, not meaning only the IT ones but every product of the mind that extends human abilities to solve a problem.
I love solve problems, I can safely say that is what I'm doing since I started to work, and perhaps before.
NicolaGuglielmi.name: Nicola Guglielmi
NicolaGuglielmi.title: GEOTEC SPA, Innovation Manager

PaoloMelchiorre.bio:
I’m a Python developer who contributes to the Django project and gives talks at tech conferences.

I’ve been a GNU/Linux user since 2000 and I use and promote Free Software.

I have a degree in Computer Science and currently I work remotely, in Pescara (Italy), for 20tab.
PaoloMelchiorre.name: Paolo Melchiorre
PaoloMelchiorre.title: www.paulox.net

DennyCasabianca.bio:
Programmatore, idealista, innovatore. Durante i suoi studi universitari Denny ha avuto modo d'interfacciarsi con 124 nazionalità diverse lavorando per una no-profit internazionale.

Fermamente convinto che nel mondo si dovrebbero costruire ponti e non muri, Denny crede che la parola "diversità" sia sinonimo di ricchezza e opportunità.
DennyCasabianca.name: Denny Casabianca

GianlucaAmato.bio: Gianluca Amato, laurea in Scienze dell'Informazione e dottorato  in Informatica,  è professore di II fascia di Logica Matematica, presso l'Unversità degli Studi "G. d'Annunzio" di Chieti-Pescara. In passato, sempre presso la stessa università, è stato ricercatore in Informatica. Geek già da tenera età, scrive la sua prima pubblicazione a 13 anni per la compianta rivista "MC Microcomputer". Per la cronaca, l'articolo è proprio sul reinforcement learning, la tecnica di apprendimento automatico usata in AlphaGo.
GianlucaAmato.name: Gianluca Amato

FrancescoSciuti.bio:
A talented and accomplished programmer extremely competent after several years of experience in enterprise programming , high skilled in web development (frontend and backend) and in team project management.

I have a keen interest in new technologies and in IT development and I’m always upgrading and evaluating my knowledge and skills to stay at the cutting-edge of web development.

My outstanding verbal and written communication skills let me involved in lots of meetings, workshop and courses both in Sicily and in Italy as a speaker and tech event organizer.

Focused on continual professional and technological improvement: books, courses, articles, forums and regular attender of tech events where I can meet new and interesting people with which exchange as much as possible ideas and technical knowledge.

I want to put myself in challenges both in the personal and professional side and this is way I’m involved ,as an active contributor, in many Italian communities (Angular ,React, Javascript ,GDG, PUG, etc…) and I contribute as a counselor to CoderDojo Foundation (Computational youth learning).

I’ve worked for a long time as a employee and then as a freelancer, but nowadays I has my own company: Acadevmy – Software Factory, founded with my friends Andrea and Salvo.
FrancescoSciuti.name: Francesco Sciuti
FrancescoSciuti.title: CEO @ Acadevmy srl

GregorioPalama.bio: Lavoro nell'industria IT da oltre 10 anni e ho esperienze in diversi settori. Attualmente, ricopro il ruolo di Project Manager e Mobile Solutions Engineer in Aesys srl. Sono costantemente alla ricerca di cose nuove da studiare e apprendere e non riesco a stare neanche un giorno senza aggiornarmi. Sono co-organizzatore del GDG Pescara assieme ad altri sviluppatori, amo condividere le mie conoscenze e cercare di farlo in maniera divertente.
GregorioPalama.name: Gregorio Palamà
GregorioPalama.shortBio: Project Manager & Senior Mobile Developer @ Aesys / Community Manager @ GDG Pescara
GregorioPalama.title: Project Manager & Senior Mobile Developer @ Aesys / Community Manager @ GDG Pescara

JunaSalviati.bio: Juna has always been curious about technology and computers so she wrote her first line of code at 10. She continued to write code and graduated as a Software Engineer. She have always been cultivating a passion for classical studies, humanities and is fascinated by communication studies and human-machine interaction.
JunaSalviati.name: Juna Salviati
JunaSalviati.title: Software Engineer

LeonardoDipilato.bio:
Aerospace Engineer by day. Tech Addict by night.
Preacher of self-study, always on the lookout for some way to mix I.T. and Aerospace.
LeonardoDipilato.name: Leonardo Dipilato
LeonardoDipilato.shortBio: Manager - GDG Pisa; Freelance ML Engineer
LeonardoDipilato.title: Manager - GDG Pisa; Freelance ML Engineer

LukaMilosevic.bio: Sono un giovane developer sempre pronto a scoprire nuove tecnologie e condividere la mia conoscenza con gli altri
LukaMilosevic.name: Luka Milosevic
LukaMilosevic.title: Junior Front-end developer @ AESYS

MichelangeloMorrillo.bio: Playing with Linux since I was 13 yo, now I'm Software Developer with a strong passion for DevOps environment.
MichelangeloMorrillo.name: Michelangelo Morrillo
MichelangeloMorrillo.title: Software Developer
